ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Examined the history and current situation in Haiti with emphasis on sustainability efforts.
This course broadened my general knowledge about Haiti and allowed me to pursue my own personal interest in sustainable energies.

This is an extremely insightful course that truly humbles anyone who truly feels like they are going to be the 'savior' of the developing world. This class grounds you, and opens your eyes to how all our stories are intertwined via world-systems theory, globalization, neo-colonialism and colonialism. It shows that underdevelopment is not just a function of poverty, and so more than wealth is required to get countries like Haiti on the trajectory to sustainability.
I became much more knowledgeable about Haitian history and culture.
A general and stepper understanding of Haiti as a country and a became a better writer
Learned about Haiti in several ways, had no prior knowledge
I gained a tremendous amount of knowledge regarding Haitis culture, history, and struggles. I also was able to become more comfortable participating in class as the semester went on.
I learned to write structured papers.
I learned a ton of import information about the culture of Haitians and the way the country has developed since its beginning

I think that I gained a better understanding of the complicated colonial history Haiti has and how it has left long lasting effects well into the future. I think I was also able to improve my essay writing skills, mainly in making myself more concise for the reader which I have always struggled with.
I learned a lot about the history and present day of a country I knew very little about. I learned important writing skills along with public speaking and small discussions amongst peers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Good in class discussions mostly, although student-led seminars were quiet at times.

The strength of this course was that it was reliant on students' own interests: Students presented seminars on topics of their choice as well as presentations on their own individual papers. The weakness of this course was the fact that much of our conversations about Haiti lacked actual Haitians' input, however, this would be difficult to solve due to the low number of Haitians at Yale currently.
Very engaging and everyone is given a chance to share and explore their interest for taking the course.
Strengths are that you have the space to grow as a writer
Great course

A strength of the course is helping transition freshman to classes at Yale. We were able to become more comfortable participating and asking questions as the semester went on. I believe the course could be improved by making it more engaging or changing up the style of presentations.
I dont think the course focuses enough on sustainable development for an EVST course.
I liked the structure of the course. I wish we did more projects about the culture of Haiti

I think the main strengths of the course was the breadth of it. It covered a large amount of information and left me feeling like I understood a lot more about Haiti than I did when I started. I didnt think there were any real weaknesses.

It was great that we read different books, wrote papers, lead class discussions and classes, learned how to find sources through the yale databases and libraries, etc. This class allowed me to learn how to create good group discussions, work with my classmates, lead a class, etc.

A strength of this course is that it was a great introduction to the seminar format and what is expected in terms of participation, presentations, and writing.
A drawback of the course was the fact that much of the information was presented as a discussion led by a student so at times it felt as if the information was slipping through the cracks and that we learned about a particular topic to the extent that the student presenter of the day had researched it. That being said, Dr. Geballe did preface the course by saying that we would by no means become experts on the subject matter which in and of itself was an important lesson.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I highly recommend this course for students considering the EVST track.

Yes, I would recommend this course to any students looking for an intellectually challenging course that they can tailor to their own interests. The workload is perfect for first years adjusting to college writing.

yes! yes! yes! It's good to learn about another experience in the world outside of your own. Moreover, there are no strict requirements, you truly get to have a lot of academic freedom, and get specific feedback to improve your writing and research skills.
Yes if they want the chance to become a better writer without having the stress of a traditional english
Yes, great discussion topics and learning style is engaging
Yes

I would recommend it if the student is looking for a writing credit, but otherwise I found that class could sometimes be repetitive in the sense that a new topic was presented but in almost the same manner ever week.
Yes. But the student must be engaged in Learning about Haiti.
Yes I would recommend this course because of the way I was able to improve my writing while learning about something I didnt have the chance to in high school

Yes I would recommend this course. I think that it is a brilliant way to improve writing skills without feeling like you are doing a writing course. It covers a very interesting country which most people would not learn about.

Yes I would highly recommend. It was the perfect amount of work load. I loved having a smaller class. It allowed me to become closer with my classmates along with my professor. It was a great course for getting some writing in while learning about a new country.
